seg.seg: Having seized the unsplittable Vajra of trustfulness, having been made trusting in the splendid banner of great compassion, having taken the servant of the establishments of the triple awareness,

excellently decorated (with the thirty two ornaments), being upright on the summit of Sumeru that roars on his own, [64] you, you are an Indra god of omniscience, with thousand eyes, seeing with exactness the good Law belonging to every era,

surrounded by the pure gods (who form four) companies, oh you, who completely destroys these kings of the Asuras which are the passions, oh you, who connects this Vermacitra of the reflection with the

(solid) bond of the god Indra! [65] Decorated with divine ornaments, having seized the lightning in your two hands, with Indra’s look you are descended for the great sacrifice. (With the nectar of) the good (Law)

you have satiated (the humans). You have plunged the company of Brahmans [and] the entire world into surprise, oh you, who tames the Indra gods, oh you, who must be brought above the head of all Indra gods and who must be placed as the first! [66]
After having received (these four) great truths of the Law [and] these endless blessings of reflection, after having abandoned the purpose of the world, you tame the powerful ones, (you pass through)

all the pitfalls of life for the city of Nirvāṇa; you left me in the middle of all suffering. But it is only in your refuge that I would like to go with all my heart for all the rest of my lives. [67] (You dressed yourself) in the lotus of mercifulness,

oh you, who is characterised by your [good] heart, having been clothed in splendid clothing, without a blemish of (shame and) modesty. The topknot [is] tightened, the entire body [is] without neglect; delicate, pure, great [is] the lustre of the omniscience. Having seized with the hand the divine
ewer [= bhṛṅgāra] (of compassion), filled with the pure nectar of amity, [68] you, [you are] an excellent god Brahman of a Buddha, unrivalled, having reached the destination ...,
oh you, who forms the beings in making them pure in eight ways, oh you, who lets the world entirely go to the land of Nirvāṇa, oh you, who really engenders the Brahmans that have sprung from your

mouth, the sons of the god Brahman of the Law. [69] You proclaimed the four Vedas who consist in the [four] truths; the fact that you are largely understood (lit. your understanding) by women and children [is] happiness [and] amusement, like the

[jewel] Cintāmaṇi of the (king) Sāgara having the cup at hand. You have let flow the pure Gaṅgā of the Law on the earth; be it that the whole world could be bathed (in the pure river in the middle) of the Land of the Law. /70/

p.note: For a detailed commentary, see 297-303, which, in translation, reads:

A first, general remark concerns the word order, which is clearly different to that of prose, because it has been adapted to the metric demands: the verb is not to be found at the end of a sentence, not even in subordinate clauses; the original order of adjective + substantive in nominal constructions is reversed in case the number of syllables of the words demands it. The metric adjustment of words is also reflected in the numerous examples of sandhi and various other phenomena, such as the use of variants of the same word, such as the adjective 'pure, spotless', which appears in the two forms astare (normal in prose) and āstre (usual in poetry), cf. above b4 (69c) in comparison with above a3 (65c), b2 (68b), b3 (68e), : a1 (71a). This fact is explained by the syncope of the closed short vowels, which also explains the manifold other doublets.

Another remarkable fact is the recurring use of a stylistic process which often renders a translation difficult. It concerns the transposition of the figure called rūpaka 'metaphorical identification' (cf. 239 and 256) from poetic Sanskrit into Tocharian. For this, Sanskrit normally uses compounds where the metaphorical term (M) follows the identified object (N), of the type bāhu-latā- 'arm-liana', i.e. 'the liana which is his arm', or 'his liana-arm'. In TB, as in TA, the average syntax is different: the metaphoric term is qualified by an adjective (with suffix B -ṣṣe, A -ṣi) derived from a proper noun, cf. the metaphor, very frequent in Sanskrit, nirvāṇa-nagara- 'the town of Nirvana' (i.e. the town that is Nirvana), translated as nervān-ṣṣa riye, cf. in our text rīne nervānṣai (67d) 'in the city of N.' and, with a very similar meaning, nervānäṣṣai kentsa (69d) 'in the land of N.'. The form often associates, as in the example just cited, a concrete object (a barrel, banner, ewer, flower, clothing, river, etc.) with an abstraction (expressed by an action or abstract noun) which serves as a metaphor, cf. above: späntaitsñentaṣṣe ... wājrä akautacce (a1, 64b), mahākarumṣe waipe (a1, 64c), täryā-ykne ymentse śmoñaṣṣe pekwe (a1-2, 64d), āñmālāṣlñeṣṣe uppālne (b1, 68a), yase-kwipeṣṣe wastsy (b2, 68b), śūkes=āstreṃ ... maittarṣśe (b3, 68d), emprenmaṣṣana vedanma (b5, 70a), gān pelaikneṣṣai (b6, 70d), etc.; or else, a god and an abstract term, cf. above: poyśiññeṣṣe ... ylaiñäkte (a2, 65a), kleśanmaṣṣeṃ ceṃ lāṃtn asūreṃts (a3, 65d), pälskoṣṣe cau wemacitreṃ (a3, 65e), pelaikneṣṣe bramñäktentse (b4-5, 69e); or even a god and the Buddha, cf. pūdñäkteṣṣe ... bramñäkte (b3, 69a). It is noticeable that this figure occurs frequently in this part of the text (as opposed to ). It is likely that certain examples would allow us to recapture the Sanskrit text which served as a model. However, the simple juxtaposition of the metaphorical and of the proper term remains possible, cf. karsalñe ākāśe (: b5, 76e) 'the space (the sky) of understanding'. The choice of one or the other formulation may be dictated by metric considerations.

For a detailed commentary, see 297-303, which, in translation, reads:
Damaged on both ends; one of two leaves.

The restoration pekwe 'bracelet' (58 n.6) is made impossible by the still visible traces, although the paper is already a little spoilt. This does not provide a plausible direct object for the verb kām- 'to carry away, to take'. In addition, at the end of the line °m[au] is much more probable than °m[o], which would correspond to a late form with monophthongisation. One can read and complete mā[ñ] (ye), which would be the syncopated form and would move the stress to the first syllable, from mañiye 'valet, servant': specifically, this form of māñye seems to be more typical of verse passages (: a5, : b6, : a4), whereas mañiye is exclusively found in prose (: a4). This noun is derived from the borrowed stem *mān 'house, habitation', which is undoubtedly of Iranian origin, cf. 31 and 437. About the accent phenomenon and the use of these syncope forms in poetry, see , chap. XVIII § 6; incidentally, the distribution of mañiye and māñye is already mentioned in 374.

"The paper is torn at the end of the line, but the reading of mā is safe. In any case, the remains of the next akṣara exclude the restauration (pekwe), as per 58, n.6. The reading kakāmo for the next word is not warranted. This form shows the expected final diphthong. After it, one can even see a trace of the expected dot at the end of the pāda. " – 9-10, note 1 (and cf. ling.comm. a1 below).
triple awareness: "This phrase transposes the notion of the three applications of awareness pertaining to a Buddha: Skt. smṛty-upasthāna-; Pāli satipatthāna- (cf. 614b)." 14, n. 15.
lāṃtn is an abbreviated form metri causa for lāṃtäṃ = lāntäṃ, oblique plural of walo 'king'.

The “four companies” (wertsiya) probably denote the four groups of gods associated with the four “great kings”, the Lokapāla 'guardians of the world', placed at the four cardinal points, namely the Gandharva, the Kumbhāṇḍa, the Nāga and the Yakṣa, cf. 25.

Vemacitra is the name of an Asura chief (509a), who was taken prisoner by the Devas, and who proved to be insolent before the assembly of gods, although his feet and his hands were bound with an extremely solid fetter; the matching person in Pāli carries the name Vepacitti, cf. II, p. 924-926. This widespread myth is referred to in the Theragāthā, 749cd baddho Mahindapāsena Vepacity āsuro yathā 'I was bound like the demon Vepaciti with the snare of Mahinda' (translation I, p. 73). The reference to the god Indra, who plays an important role in this myth, allows to suggest a better restoration of the text than the one envisaged by Thomas (58 n. 9), brought about by his inaccurate reading [m]ai of the last syllable before the gap.

"The reading prayla, as per 58 is excluded; the reading praylu was confirmed by Couvreur (cf. 103, n.1). This is the expected form of the voc.sg.masc. of the gerundive pralye (cf. 103, § 123.1)." 10, note 3.

s(t)a(mäṣlu): What remains of the initial ligature of the word, before the tear in the paper, excludes any vocalization on top of the akṣara; the restitution si(maucai), proposed by Thomas (58 n.12), is then impossible. It is easy to restitute the voc. sg. of stamäṣle = stamäṣṣälle, verbal adjective of obligation (gerund I), with passive value, relating to the present form of the transitive verb (causative) stäm- 'to raise, to establish' (suppletive stem of käly- 'to stand up'), 3rd sg. act. stamäṣṣäm.

"The spelling ilai° instead of ylai° can be accounted for by the metrical constraint which requires a word of 4 syllables here in order to complete the first 8-syllable segment of the pāda. There is no trace of the double dot on the top of the akṣara ña of ñakteṃ. Compare the correct writing of the gen.pl. of the same word shortly afterwards." 10, note 2.

(empre)nma: For the last akṣara of the word, a reading [rmv] (hence the restitution āyormeṃ, as given in 58 n.13) is impossible, whereas the reading [nma] is possible, allowing to complete with (empre)nma, the plural of empreṃ 'truth', which offers an appropriate meaning.

"The verb (yātäst, 2 sg.act. of the present of the verb yāt- 'to tame'), if correctly restored, is in the present, while the other finite verbs nearby are in the past tense. Nonetheless, there are some other verbs in the present in the passage, and this may be the case for the verb in the next sentence. For the latter, an alternative would be the preterit participle kätau as predicate. Accordingly, the passage would be a vivd recital of the deeds of the Buddha." 14-15, n. 18.

pälskoṣṣana – "Sic! This word is not written with a Fremdzeichen for the first akṣara, as is usual. Compare further occurrences of pälsko in [a3 and : a3]. [...] snay – Sic! For snai, a sandhi form before the vowel which does not change the prosody. [...] [At the end of this line, t]he paper is torn, so the reading remains tentative as well as the restoration." 10, notes 5-7.
ñiś\ – "Sic! Virāma stroke after the plain sign, not a Fremdzeichen." 10, note 8.

jaṭ(ä): The reading jaṭ is sure, with the last sign marked by a virāma stroke. However, the meter suggests a reading jaṭä, with two syllables, in order to complete the first segment of 5 syllables. The word is an already known Sanskrit loan jaṭā- 'braid, bun, topknot' (409a) referring to the knot on the head of the Brahman ascetics.
topknot "This refers to the twisted hair on the top of the head of ascetics (cf. 409a)." 15, n. 19.

bhrängār: The word is an already known loan from Sanskrit, bhṛṅgṅāra- (765c), which refers to a kind of ewer, a precious metal container designed to cup water and considered as one of the royal attributes, cf. . The restitution of the precedent word relies on a similar passage from another text of the Buddhastotra known from a manuscript in Berlin: : a2 karuṇäṣṣe bhṛṅkār eṅku ṣärsa ymeṣṣe 'having grasped the ewer of compassion with the hand of the consciousness'.

nervānäṣṣai: Although this word should have been written with 4 syllables, it must be read with 3 syllables in order to get the first segment of 5 syllables from a pada of 13 syllables; in other words, the vowel -ä- of the third syllable is syncopated and the form has the same length as nervānṣai attested above (b1, 67d). That is a reversed phenomenon to the one observed for line b2 above. In a contradictory fashion, it can be observed that the different notations of the same form reflect their prosodic value. Cf. also wätkāltsñe (: b1), 3 syllables in 74d vs. wätkāltsäññe (: b4), 4 syllables in 76b.

(ve)danna: For the second syllable of this word, the reading [d]a is practically certain, so reading [r] is to be excluded. The dimension of the preceding gap is just sufficient for a round letter like ve. The restitution (ve)danma proposed by Couvreur, must then be admitted, although it was refused by Thomas (59 n.5): it does make perfect sense.

(sak)w n(ā)rm: The paper is torn, and one akṣara is completely lost; therefore, only the lower elements of the important ligature which precedes the akṣara rmci can be made out, whence a reading and restitution (sak)[w n](ā)rm ci; the last word is the obl. of the pronoun of the 2nd person singular twe, and the first is sakw 'pleasure, happiness', attested above in the plural skwanma (a6, 67b). The structure of nārm is identical to that of several nouns: B ṣarm 'reason, cause', yarm 'measure', sārm 'semen'; some are loaned from Sanskrit nouns in -ma- or in -man-, nom. sg. neut. -ma, cf. B abhidhārm, A abhidharm (Skt. abhidharma-), B kārm, A kāräm (Skt. karman-), AB *mā̆rm, pl. tant. B marmanma, A marmañ 'veins' (Skt. marman-). It is thus legitimate to interpret nārm (perhaps narm) as a loan from Skt. narman- neut. 'amusement, divertissement, pleasantry' (530a). This noun forms a conceptual pair with the precedent term, of the type saim waste 'refuge [and] protection'.

karute-ṣiryeṃ: This passage is difficult to read because of the condition of the paper and the partial erasing of the handwriting, but the first akṣara of the question word is [ṣ]i, rather than [p]i (pace 59). This permits to read ṣiryeṃ, second member of a compound karute-ṣiryeṃ, epithet to the oblique sg. masc. of the proper noun that follows, sāgari, gen. sg. of sāgare, a loan from Skt. Sāgara-, the name of a Nāga king (589a). The word karute (hapax) is a loan from Sanskrit karoṭa- or karoṭi- (255c; 169b), which designates a cup made from a skullcap. This object is the attribute of a variety of spirits or rancorous deities cf. 13. More precisely, the compound karoṭa-pāni 'who holds a cup in the hand' denotes a class of spirits associated with the Nāgas, or a class of Yakṣa, cf. I, p. 533. The Tocharian compound B karute-ṣirye is a calque of this term, which includes as first member a loan from Sanskrit (via a Middle-Indian intermediary) and as second member an adjective *ṣirye ‹ *ṣär-ye derived from the well-known word for 'hand', T B ṣar ‹ *ṣär. The restitution of the comparison at the beginning of the pāda relies on a legend known from a TA text, the Puṇyavanta-Jātaka, which tells how a Bodhisattva acquired the Cintāmani jewel guarded by the king Sāgara (cf. : b2-6). This mythological reference (70c) aims to reinforce the preceding statement (70b): “you obtain as pleasure the understanding of your teaching by women and children, like (i.e. as easily as) the jewel guarded by the Nāga was acquired by you”.

pi: Thomas (59 n.8) considers this syllable to contain piś 'five' with sandhi with the beginning of the following word: this would be an abbreviation of the well-known expression piś-cmelaṣṣe śaiṣṣe 'the world is made up of 5 births'. This remains possible, but pi can perfectly well be taken as the particle that accompanies the interrogation form or the modal forms, such as the optative, which is effectively the case here.

having the cup at hand: "This attribute is found with Nāgas and Yakṣas. The cup in question is made of the skull or cranium: Skt. karoṭa- or karoṭi- (cf. 255c; 169b). Skt. Sāgara- is the name of a king of Nāgas (cf. 589a), who possessed the cintāmaṇi gem, through which all wishes come true." 15, n. 21.

(wṣeṃ)ñaiś – "Virāma stroke after the plain sign, not the Fremdzeichen, see above [b1]. As for the beginning of the word, the damaged paper and the size of the break allow us to assume a large and complex ligature." 10, note 13.

p.hi: ahaṃ va ity anāthānāṃ sānāthyam avaghoṣayan //
brāhmaṇā brahmaṇaḥ putrā aurasā mukhajā iti /
mahānāgair iva svairam api kṣuṇṇaḥ kumārakaiḥ /

This noun forms a conceptual pair with the precedent term, of the type saim waste 'refuge [and] protection'.

b6. karute-ṣiryeṃ: This passage is difficult to read because of the condition of the paper and the partial erasing of the handwriting, but the first akṣara of the question word is [ṣ]i, rather than [p]i (pace [[Krause and Thomas, TEB II]]: 59). This permits to read ṣiryeṃ, second member of a compound karute-ṣiryeṃ, epithet to the oblique sg. masc. of the proper noun that follows, sāgari, gen. sg. of sāgare, a loan from Skt. Sāgara-, the name of a Nāga king ([[Edgerton BHSD]]: 589a). The word karute (hapax) is a loan from Sanskrit karoṭa- or karoṭi- ([[M-W]]: 255c; [[Edgerton BHSD]]: 169b), which designates a cup made from a skullcap. This object is the attribute of a variety of spirits or rancorous deities cf. [[de Mallmann 1975]]: 13. More precisely, the compound karoṭa-pāni 'who holds a cup in the hand' denotes a class of spirits associated with the Nāgas, or a class of Yakṣa, cf. [[Malalasekera 1937-1938]]: I, p. 533. The Tocharian compound B karute-ṣirye is a calque of this term, which includes as first member a loan from Sanskrit (via a Middle-Indian intermediary) and as second member an adjective *ṣirye ‹ *ṣär-ye derived from the well-known word for 'hand', T B ṣar ‹ *ṣär. The restitution of the comparison at the beginning of the pāda relies on a legend known from a TA text, the Puṇyavanta-Jātaka, which tells how a Bodhisattva acquired the Cintāmani jewel guarded by the king Sāgara (cf. [[A 1]]: b2-6). This mythological reference (70c) aims to reinforce the preceding statement (70b): “you obtain as pleasure the understanding of your teaching by women and children, like (i.e. as easily as) the jewel guarded by the Nāga was acquired by you”.

b6. pi: Thomas ([[Krause and Thomas, TEB II]]: 59 n.8) considers this syllable to contain piś 'five' with sandhi with the beginning of the following word: this would be an abbreviation of the well-known expression piś-cmelaṣṣe śaiṣṣe 'the world is made up of 5 births'. This remains possible, but pi can perfectly well be taken as the particle that accompanies the interrogation form or the modal forms, such as the optative, which is effectively the case here.


Stylistic remarks:

A first, general remark concerns the word order, which is clearly different to that of prose, because it has been adapted to the metric demands: the verb is not to be found at the end of a sentence, not even in subordinate clauses; the original order of adjective + substantive in nominal constructions is reversed in case the number of syllables of the words demands it. The metric adjustment of words is also reflected in the numerous examples of sandhi and various other phenomena, such as the use of variants of the same word, such as the adjective 'pure, spotless', which appears in the two forms astare (normal in prose) and āstre (usual in poetry), cf. above b4 (69c) in comparison with above a3 (65c), b2 (68b), b3 (68e), [[SI P 2]]: a1 (71a). This fact is explained by the syncope of the closed short vowels, which also explains the manifold other doublets.

Another remarkable fact is the recurring use of a stylistic process which often renders a translation difficult. It concerns the transposition of the figure called rūpaka 'metaphorical identification' (cf. [[Gerow 1971]]: 239 and 256) from poetic Sanskrit into Tocharian. For this, Sanskrit normally uses compounds where the metaphorical term (M) follows the identified object (N), of the type bāhu-latā- 'arm-liana', i.e. 'the liana which is his arm', or 'his liana-arm'. In TB, as in TA, the average syntax is different: the metaphoric term is qualified by an adjective (with suffix B -ṣṣe, A -ṣi) derived from a proper noun, cf. the metaphor, very frequent in Sanskrit, nirvāṇa-nagara- 'the town of Nirvana' (i.e. the town that is Nirvana), translated as nervān-ṣṣa riye, cf. in our text rīne nervānṣai (67d) 'in the city of N.' and, with a very similar meaning, nervānäṣṣai kentsa (69d) 'in the land of N.'. The form often associates, as in the example just cited, a concrete object (a barrel, banner, ewer, flower, clothing, river, etc.) with an abstraction (expressed by an action or abstract noun) which serves as a metaphor, cf. above: späntaitsñentaṣṣe ... wājrä akautacce (a1, 64b), mahākarumṣe waipe (a1, 64c), täryā-ykne ymentse śmoñaṣṣe pekwe (a1-2, 64d), āñmālāṣlñeṣṣe uppālne (b1, 68a), yase-kwipeṣṣe wastsy (b2, 68b), śūkes=āstreṃ ... maittarṣśe (b3, 68d), emprenmaṣṣana vedanma (b5, 70a), gān pelaikneṣṣai (b6, 70d), etc.; or else, a god and an abstract term, cf. above: poyśiññeṣṣe ... ylaiñäkte (a2, 65a), kleśanmaṣṣeṃ ceṃ lāṃtn asūreṃts (a3, 65d), pälskoṣṣe cau wemacitreṃ (a3, 65e), pelaikneṣṣe bramñäktentse (b4-5, 69e); or even a god and the Buddha, cf. pūdñäkteṣṣe ... bramñäkte (b3, 69a). It is noticeable that this figure occurs frequently in this part of the text (as opposed to [[SI P 2]]). It is likely that certain examples would allow us to recapture the Sanskrit text which served as a model. However, the simple juxtaposition of the metaphorical and of the proper term remains possible, cf. karsalñe ākāśe ([[SI P 2]]: b5, 76e) 'the space (the sky) of understanding'. The choice of one or the other formulation may be dictated by metric considerations.

Damaged on both ends; one of two leaves.

a1 Having seized the unsplittable Vajra of trustfulness, having been made trusting in the splendid banner of great compassion, having taken the servant of the establishments of the triple awareness, a2 excellently decorated (with the thirty two ornaments), being upright on the summit of Sumeru that roars on his own, [64] you, you are an Indra god of omniscience, with thousand eyes, seeing with exactness the good Law belonging to every era, a3 surrounded by the pure gods (who form four) companies, oh you, who completely destroys these kings of the Asuras which are the passions, oh you, who connects this Vermacitra of the reflection with the a4 (solid) bond of the god Indra! [65] Decorated with divine ornaments, having seized the lightning in your two hands, with Indra’s look you are descended for the great sacrifice. (With the nectar of) the good (Law) a5 you have satiated (the humans). You have plunged the company of Brahmans [and] the entire world into surprise, oh you, who tames the Indra gods, oh you, who must be brought above the head of all Indra gods and who must be placed as the first! [66] a6 After having received (these four) great truths of the Law [and] these endless blessings of reflection, after having abandoned the purpose of the world, you tame the powerful ones, (you pass through) b1 all the pitfalls of life for the city of Nirvāṇa; you left me in the middle of all suffering. But it is only in your refuge that I would like to go with all my heart for all the rest of my lives. [67] (You dressed yourself) in the lotus of mercifulness, b2 oh you, who is characterised by your [good] heart, having been clothed in splendid clothing, without a blemish of (shame and) modesty. The topknot [is] tightened, the entire body [is] without neglect; delicate, pure, great [is] the lustre of the omniscience. Having seized with the hand the divine b3 ewer [= bhṛṅgāra] (of compassion), filled with the pure nectar of amity, [68] you, [you are] an excellent god Brahman of a Buddha, unrivalled, having reached the destination ..., b4 oh you, who forms the beings in making them pure in eight ways, oh you, who lets the world entirely go to the land of Nirvāṇa, oh you, who really engenders the Brahmans that have sprung from your b5 mouth, the sons of the god Brahman of the Law. [69] You proclaimed the four Vedas who consist in the [four] truths; the fact that you are largely understood (lit. your understanding) by women and children [is] happiness [and] amusement, like the b6 [jewel] Cintāmaṇi of the (king) Sāgara having the cup at hand. You have let flow the pure Gaṅgā of the Law on the earth; be it that the whole world could be bathed (in the pure river in the middle) of the Land of the Law. /70/
